facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer owned considerable properties in the Tirunelveli district.

anchor.surface_text: One Lakshminarayana Iyer, a Hindu Brahmin, who owned companysiderable properties in the Tirunelveli district, died on 13th December, 1924, leaving him surviving a widow Ranganayaki, and a married daughter Ramalakshmi.

facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer died on 13th December 1924.

anchor.surface_text: One Lakshminarayana Iyer, a Hindu Brahmin, who owned companysiderable properties in the Tirunelveli district, died on 13th December, 1924, leaving him surviving a widow Ranganayaki, and a married daughter Ramalakshmi.

facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer left surviving a widow Ranganayaki and a married daughter Ramalakshmi.

anchor.surface_text: died on 13th December, 1924, leaving him surviving a widow Ranganayaki, and a married daughter Ramalakshmi. Ramalakshmi had married the plaintiff and had a number of children from him.

facts.text: Ramalakshmi had married the plaintiff and had a number of children from him who were all alive in December 1924.

anchor.surface_text: Ramalakshmi had married the plaintiff and had a number of children from him. They were all alive in December, 1924, when Lakshminarayana died, Before his death he executed a will on 16th November, 1924,

facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer executed a will on 16th November 1924.

anchor.surface_text: They were all alive in December, 1924, when Lakshminarayana died, Before his death he executed a will on 16th November, 1924, the companystruction of which is in companytroversy in this appeal.

facts.text: By the will, Ranganayaki Amminal was to enjoy the entire properties till her lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: By this will he gave the following directions -- After my lifetime, you, the aforesaid Ranganayaki Amminal, my wife, shall till your lifetime, enjoy the aforesaid entire properties, the outstandings due to me, the debts payable by me, and the chit amounts payable by me.

facts.text: After Ranganayaki's lifetime, Ramalakshmi Ammal and her heirs were to enjoy the properties with absolute rights and powers of alienation.

anchor.surface_text: After your lifetime Ramalakshmi Ammal, our daughter and wife of Rama Ayyar Avergal of Melagaram village, and her heirs shall enjoy them with absolute rights and powers of alienation such as gift, exchange, and sale from son to grandson and so on for generations.

facts.text: The will directed Ranganayaki to pay maintenance to Chinnanmal alias Lakshmi Ammal and obtain a release deed.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the payment of maintenance to be made to Chinnanmal alias Lakshmi Ammal, wife of my late son Hariharamayyan, my wife Ranganayaki Ammal shall pay the same as she pleases, and obtain a release deed.

facts.text: Ranganayaki entered into possession of the properties on the death of her husband.

anchor.surface_text: Ranganayaki entered into possession of the properties on the death of her husband. On 21st February, 1928, she settled the maintenance claim of Lakshmi Ammal

facts.text: On 21st February 1928, Ranganayaki settled maintenance claim of Lakshmi Ammal by paying Rs. 3,350 cash and agreeing to pay Rs. 240 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: On 21st February, 1928, she settled the maintenance claim of Lakshmi Ammal and obtained a deed of release from her by paying her a sum of Rs. 3,350 in cash and by executing in her favour an agreement stipulating to pay her a sum of Rs. 240 per annum.

facts.text: Ramalakshmi died on 25th April 1938 during the lifetime of the widow.

anchor.surface_text: Ramalakshmi died on 25th April, 1938 during the lifetime of the widow. None of her children survived her.

facts.text: None of Ramalakshmi's children survived her.

anchor.surface_text: Ramalakshmi died on 25th April, 1938 during the lifetime of the widow. None of her children survived her. On the 24th July, 1945, the widow describing herself as an absolute owner

facts.text: On 24th July 1945, the widow sold one item of property to the 2nd defendant for Rs. 500.

anchor.surface_text: On the 24th July, 1945, the widow describing herself as an absolute owner of the properties of her husband sold one of the items of the property to the 2nd defendant for Rs. 500.

facts.text: Suit instituted on 18th September 1945 by plaintiff, husband and sole heir of Ramalakshmi, for declaration that the sale not binding beyond widow's lifetime and restrain alienation.

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th September, 1945, the suit out of which this appeal arises was instituted by the plaintiff, the husband and the sole heir of Ramalakshmi, for a declaration that the said sale would number be binding on him beyond the lifetime of the widow.

facts.text: On 19th September 1945, ad interim injunction issued restraining widow from alienating properties.

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th September, 1945, an ad interim injunction was issued by the High Court restraining the widow from alienating the properties in her possession and forming part of her husbands estate,

facts.text: On 27th September 1945, despite injunction, widow executed two deeds of settlement in favour of other defendants.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of this injunction, on the 27th September, 1945, she executed two deeds of settlement in favour of the other defendants companyprising a number of properties.

facts.text: Plaintiff averred Ramalakshmi obtained vested interest under the will.

anchor.surface_text: It was averred in the plaint that Ramalakshmi obtained a vested interest in the suit -properties under the will of her father and plaintiff was thus entitled to maintain the suit.

facts.text: Defendants pleaded plaintiff had no title, widow entitled to absolute estate or at least widow's estate, daughter's estate contingent.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants pleaded that the plaintiff had numbertitle to maintain the suit, that the widow was entitled under the will to an absolute estate or at least to an estate analogous to and number less than a widows estate, that the estate given to Ramalakshmi under the will was but a companytingent one

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Tinnevelly in OS No. 50 of 1945 gave judgment on 13th August 1946 holding widow had limited life interest, daughter vested interest, granted declaratory decree.

anchor.surface_text: The subordinate judge held that the widow took under the will a limited life, interest, and number an absolute estate or even a widows estate under Hindu law, and that the daughter got thereunder a vested interest in the properties to which the plaintiff succeeded on her death.

facts.text: High Court of Judicature at Madras in Appeal No. 635 of 1946 gave judgment on 27th February 1950 affirming trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated the 27th February, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Madras  Rao and Ayyar JJ.  in Appeal No. 635 of 1946 arising, out of judgment and decree dated the 13th August, 1946,

facts.text: Widow died on 14th February 1948 during pendency of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The unsuccessful defendants preferred an appeal against this decree to the High Court of Judicature at Madras. During the pendency of the appeal the widow died on 14th February, 1948.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal admitted on 27th November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment under appeal affirmed the decision of the trial judge and maintained his view on the companystruction of the will. Leave to appeal to the Supreme Court was granted and the appeal was admitted on the 27th November, 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court held widow had limited life estate, not Hindu widow's estate, daughter had vested interest.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the estate companyferred on Ranganayaki Ammal was more like the limited estate in the English sense of the term than like a full Hindu widows estate in spite of the directions above- mentioned.

facts.text: Original Suit No. 50 of 1945 in Court of Subordinate Judge of Tinnevelly.

issues.text: whether the widow took under the will an absolute estate or an estate like the Hindu widows estate and whether the daughters interest therein was in the nature of a contingent remainder, or whether she got in the properties a vested interest.

anchor.surface_text: According to Jarman on Wills , the law leans in favour of vesting of estates and the property disposed of belongs to the object of the gift when the will takes effect and we think the daughter got under this will a vested interest in the testators properties on his death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express terms; implication rejected as properties yielded sufficient income, widow managed 21 years without alienating except substitution; limited power if any falls short of full Hindu widow powers
